subject: Re: Quickscript Manual
msgSnippet: That s actually a solved problem these days; all browsers support at least one web font format (whether WOFF, TrueType, or EOT). I m somewhat surprised and
messageBody:
That's actually a solved problem these days; all browsers support at least one web font format (whether WOFF, TrueType, or EOT). I'm somewhat surprised and dismayed that this functionality isn't used more liberally among QS fans with websites.

The trouble with something like this is that one of the functions of _The Quickscript Alphabet_ is to answer questions like:

* What are the ranges of acceptable sizes for the loop in Out (#37)?
* Is it permissible/forbidden/required for the Tall part of key (#5) to be curved?

These sorts of questions aren't answerable if the entire scanned PDF were to be typeset using modern methods; it'd be like trying to learn cursive when the textbooks are all typeset in Times New Roman, and don't have a faux-handwriting typefaceand there's no teacher to show you her cursiveor fellow students, for that matter.

This problem could be alleviated somewhat with Quickscript fonts with loads of OpenType features  say, the sorts of "combine these letters in sequence to display as this other character" fancypants stuff as seen on <http://symbolset.com/>. I don't think anyone's willing to put in that kind of time, though, and it'd still be only one font. Wouldn't give anyone a sense of the permissible variation that happens in normal handwriting.

--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "Moira O'Brien" <moira.obrien@...> wrote:
>
> The difficulty with converting to a text document is the display of the QS
> characters. Unless the reader has a QS font loaded, the display will be
> gobbledegook.
>
> *Moira*
>
>

>
> > **
> >
> >
> > Hi all... I've had a pdf of the Quickscript Manual for over a decade, and
> > it looks like that's the same one that is still circulating today.
> >
> > I was wondering if anyone has ever converted it to a normal text document
> > for easier publication on the web, eBooks, etc? Or are there copyright
> > issues there that I'm not aware of?
> >
> >
> >
>
